list.title: Question 43
list.content:
Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom would produce the shortest wavelength?


- A.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 1s$
- B.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 2s$
- C.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 3s$
- D.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 4s$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The shortest wavelength corresponds to a higher frequency and therefore a higher energy transition. The $5p$ to $1s$ represents the largest energy drop and therefore would produce the shortest wavelength.

list.title: Question 44
list.content:
An electron in a hydrogen atom transitions from $n = 1$  to $n = 4$, which statement below best describes the energy involved in this transition?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is absorbed in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is emitted in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is absorbed in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is emitted in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Transitions from energy levels $n = 2, 3, 4\ldots$ to $n = 1$ represent the largest energy transitions due to the convergence of energy levels moving away from the nucleus.
A transition from $n = 4 \longrightarrow n = 1$  emits in the UV range of the spectrum. Since the proposed transition is from $n = 1$ to $n = 4$, ultraviolet light is absorbed rather than emitted.

list.title: Question 45
list.content: John is sitting on a beach on a warm summer evening watching the reddish sky ($\lambda=650$ nm) while his brother, Eric, is playing with his laser beam with a frequency of $4.60\times 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}$. - Calculate the frequency of the radiation from the red sky. [1] - Calculate the wavelength of the laser beam of Eric. [1] - Compare the wavelength of the laser beam with the wavelength of the radiation of the red sky. [1] - Deduce the colour of the laser beam of Eric. [1]
list.markScheme:
- $\begin{aligned}
  \\
  f &= \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}}{650\times 10^{-9}\,\text{m}} \\
  f &= \answer{4.62\times 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \text{Rearranging the formula: } c &= \lambda f, \\
  \text{We obtain: } f &= \dfrac{c}{\lambda} \\
  \end{aligned}$
- $\begin{aligned}
  \\
  \lambda &= \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}}{4.60\times 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}} \\
  \lambda &= \answer{652\,\text{nm}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \text{Rearranging the formula: } c &= \lambda f, \\
  \text{We obtain: } f &= \dfrac{c}{\lambda} \\
  \end{aligned}$
- The wavelength of the laser beam and the red sky is almost the same, which is 650 nm vs 652 nm. $\checkmark$
- Since the laser beam and red sky have a very similar wavelength, the colour of the laser beam is also red. $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
Successive ionization energies for an unknown element are given in the table below.


- Ionization energy / $\mathbf{kJ\ mol^{-1}}$First ionization energy494Second ionization energy4562Third ionization energy6912Fourth ionization energy9543

To which element the trend above for successive ionization energies belong to?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Li
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Na
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Mg
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Al
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Students must understand that patterns in successive ionization energies give evidence for the energy levels in the atom.
From the given data, we can see a significant increase from first to second ionization energy. This jump between the first and second ionization energy indicates that the second electron is removed from a lower energy level. As a result, we can conclude that the element has one valence electron and belongs to group 1.
The element has at least 4 electrons, so it cannot be lithium.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as the student must deduce the group of an element from its successive ionization energy data.

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
Which is not a possible orbital-box diagram?


- $\hspace{0.9em}$$\textrm{A.}$$\hspace{0.em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/78b9add3-0086-4d1a-98d1-fbf9a07a22ff/2-681a.png)

B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/0e485853-372a-4b6c-bffe-116908ba27e3/2-681b.png)

C.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/1a0a2d5c-896c-4443-8a01-3b5e55f7d3ac/2-681c.png)

D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/020bc511-da0e-46d9-a097-f28de93e7d96/2-681d.png)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Orbital diagrams must follow three rules: the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle.
Options A and C are the orbital diagrams for copper and chromium respectively $-$ the two exceptions to completely filling the $4s$ orbital before the $3d$ orbital.
Option B is the orbital diagram for either the copper(I) ion or the zinc (II) ion as $4s$ electrons are removed before $3d$ electrons.
This leaves Option D as the option that is not possible as it is what we would expect the orbital diagram to be for copper if it followed the trend that $4s$ orbitals are filled before $3d$ orbitals. As $4s$ electrons are removed before $3d$ electrons, this cannot be the orbital diagram for any ions either. A full $3d$ subshell is more stable.

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
An element has the electron configuration $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$. Which of the below gives this element the correct number of energy levels, block, and group?


- Energy levelsBlockGroupA.$\hspace{1em}$3$s$2B.$\hspace{1em}$3$d$7C.$\hspace{1em}$4$s$7D.$\hspace{1em}$4$d$9
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This highest principal energy level is 4 ($4s^2$).
The subshell being filled is $3d$, making it a $d-$block element. Its position in the $d-$block and the total number of valence electrons, being 9 ($4s^2 + 3d^7$), places this element in group 9.

list.title: Question 49
list.content: Consider the data below on the successive ionization energies for $\ce{Al}.$ - $\enskip$Electrons Removed$\enskip$1234$\textbf{Energy(kJ mol}\mathbf{^{-1}})$$\enskip577\enskip$$\enskip1816\enskip$$\enskip2881\enskip$$\enskip11600\enskip$ - - Explain why the successive ionization energies for an element increase. [1] - Explain how the successive ionization energies for aluminium give evidence for its three valence electrons. [2] - Using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet, calculate the wavelength of light required to remove an electron from an aluminium atom. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - As electrons are removed, there is less electron- electron repulsion, so the remaining electrons are pulled closer to the nucleus and more energy is required to remove them$.\, \checkmark$
  - There is a large increase in ionization energy between the 3rd and 4th electron, indicating that the 4th electron is removed from a different (lower/closer) energy level.  $\checkmark$
    The 4th electron is removed from an energy level closer to the nucleus, with stronger forces of attraction, so aluminium has three electrons in its valence shell. $\checkmark$

- $\mbox{}$
$\begin{aligned}
  IE &= (L)(E) \Longrightarrow E = \dfrac{IE}{L} = \dfrac{577\times 10^3}{6.02\times 10^{23}} = 9.58\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}\, \checkmark \\
  E &= (h)(f) \Longrightarrow f = \dfrac{E}{h} = \dfrac{9.58\times 10^{-19}}{6.63\times10^{-34}} = 1.45\times 10^{15}\,\text{Hz}\, \checkmark \\
  c &= (\lambda)(f) \Longrightarrow \lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3\times 10^{8}}{1.45\times10^{15}} \\
  &= \answer{2.08\times 10^{-7}\text{m}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 50
list.content: The wavelength of light emitted for the $n=\infty \rightarrow 1$ transition for an electron in a zinc atom is $296\, nm.$ - - Define first ionization energy. [2] - Write an equation that represents the first ionization energy of zinc. [1] - Using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet, calculate the first ionization energy of zinc in kJ mol$^{-1}$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The minimum energy required to remove one mole of electrons $\checkmark$ from one mole of gaseous atoms. $\checkmark$
  - $\ce{Zn(g) -> Zn+(g) + e-}\, \checkmark$
    State symbols required

- $\mbox{}$
$\begin{aligned}
  c &= (\lambda)(f) \Longrightarrow f = \dfrac{c}{\lambda}=\dfrac{3\times10^8\text{m s}^{-1}}{296\times 10^{-9}\text{m}} = 1.01\times10^{15}\text{Hz}\, \checkmark  \\
  E &= (h)(f) \Longrightarrow E = (6.63\times 10^{-34}\text{J s})(1.01\times 10^{15}\text{s}^{-1}) = 6.72\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}\,\checkmark \\
  IE &= (L)(E) \Longrightarrow IE = (6.02\times 10^{23})(6.72\times 10^{-19}) = 404544\,\text{J mol}^{-1} \\
  &= \answer{405\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  Ionization energy is the energy required to move an electron from the ground state to the infinite level and so can be expressed as $n = 1\rightarrow \infty$ (requiring the same energy as would be emitted for the reverse process, 296 nm).
  L refers to Avogadro's number (N$_A$).

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
Which of the following does NOT have two valence electrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Al$^+$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Zn
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ca
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Sc$^{3+}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electron configuration of Al$^+$: [Ne] $3s^2$
Electron configuration of Zn: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^{10}$
Electron configuration of Ca: [Ar] $4s^2$
Electron configuration of Sc: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^1$.
Sc will lose 2 electrons in the 4s sublevel and 1 from the 3d sublevel, leaving a complete 3rd energy level with 8 valence electrons in Sc$^{3+}$ ($1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6$).

list.title: Question 52
list.content:
How many fully occupied $p$ orbitals are there in selenium, Se, atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$2
- B. $\hspace{1em}$3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$7
- D. $\hspace{1em}$9
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Selenium's electron configuration is $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^{10}\,4p^4$.
The three $2p$ and three $3p$ orbitals are fully occupied, along with one $4p$ orbital.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89bd9bcb-c836-45ae-92f4-7c208e7e6ff5/images/116855d7-2a12-459d-ac3b-c43a03ebefb5/image.png)

list.title: Question 53
list.content:
Which of the following statements about $p$ orbitals are correct?


- I.A $2p$ orbital has the same shape as a $3p$ orbital.II.Electrons in the $2p$ orbital are, on average, closer to the nucleus than electrons in the $3p$ orbital.III.The angle between the $p_x$ and $p_y$ orbitals is $90^\circ.$



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
All $p$ orbitals share the same fundamental dumbbell shape, regardless of their energy level. A $2p$ and a $3p$ orbital have identical shapes but differ in size and energy: the $3p$ orbital is larger and has higher energy. Statement I is correct.
While $2p$ and $3p$ orbitals belong to different energy levels, electrons in a $2p$ orbital are, on average, found closer to the nucleus than those in a $3p$ orbital. This is because as the energy level increases, the average distance between the electron and the nucleus increases as well.  Statement II is also correct.
Finally, the three $p$ orbitals $(p_x, p_y,\text{ and } p_z)$ are oriented along mutually perpendicular axes in three$-$dimensional space. The angle between any two of them, such as $p_x$ and $p_y,$ is $90^\circ.$ Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 54
list.content:
How many fully occupied $p$ orbitals are present in a ground$\text{--}$state arsenic (As) atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$2
- B. $\hspace{1em}$3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$6
- D. $\hspace{1em}$7
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From its placement in Period 4 of the periodic table, arsenic will have two completely filled $p$ subshells, or 6 filled $p$ orbitals. The condensed electron configuration of arsenic is  $[\text{Ar}]\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^3.$ Hund's rule reminds us that the three valence $p$ electrons in arsenic will singly$\text{--}$occupy the three $4p$ orbitals. There will be 6 fully occupied $p$ orbitals.

list.title: Question 55
list.content:
Which electrons are lost in the formation of a copper (II)  ion from a copper atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$One $3s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- B. $\hspace{1em}$One $4s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Two $4s$ electrons
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Two $3d$ electrons
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{Cu}$ has the electron configuration $\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1\,3d^{10}$ (a full d-subshell is more stable). The $4s$ electron is lost in the first ionization followed by a $3d$ electron.

list.title: Question 56
list.content:
How many unpaired electrons are in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$3
- C.$\hspace{1em}$1
- D.$\hspace{1em}$2
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Manganese atoms have 25 electrons and have the electron configuration
Mn: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 4s^2 3d^5$
according to the aufbau principle.  When transition metals lose electrons, they lose them from the sublevel with the highest $n-$level.  For Mn, the two electrons are lost from the $4s$ sublevel to form the ion $\ce{Mn^2+}$.
$\ce{Mn^{2+}}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^5$
To determine the number of unpaired electrons, we can draw the orbital box diagram and use Hund's law which maximizes the number of unpaired electrons in partially filled sublevels.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e265c959-7bc9-4194-ba46-8554199f8bb3/images/9a9bc6c8-e8b3-49c5-af73-68b3320ed6a3/CH0777.png)


There are five unpaired electrons in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion.

list.title: Question 57
list.content: The Bohr model of the atom can be used to explain the observed emission and absorption spectra of the hydrogen atom. - - Sketch an energy level diagram for the hydrogen atom and draw on it to show an electron transition from $n = 2$ to $n = 5$. [2] - Indicate if an emission or absorption spectrum would be more appropriate for observing this transition. [1] - Indicate the portion of the electromagnetic spectrum in which this transition would be observed. [1] - Another transition is observed from $n = 4$ to $n = 1$. Is the observed spectral line for this transition expected to have a shorter or longer wavelength than the $n = 2$ to $n = 5$ transition? Explain your answer. [2] - Electrons transitioning from $n = 4$ to $n = 1$ emit 1228 kJ mol$^{-1}$. - Calculate the energy involved for a single electron undergoing this transition in Joules. [1] - Calculate the wavelength of light emitted by this transition. [2] - Identify the portion of the electromagnetic spectrum where this transition would be observed. [1] - Describe why this observed transition supports the Bohr model of the atom with respect to energy being quantized. [2] $\ $
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Five energy levels are drawn, labeled $n = 1$ to $n = 5$ with the higher energy levels converging as the energy level increases. $\checkmark$
    The transition arrow is drawn in an upward direction from $n = 2$ to $n = 5$. $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6193c6a-debf-439d-8c72-9e31753671f2/images/762a2896-5d31-4ed2-bd34-68a4302304b2/CH0785.png)


    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The lines representing the energy levels must converge at higher levels because the energy levels within the atom converge away from the nucleus. The arrow must begin at $n = 2$ and point to $n = 5$ to indicate the direction of the transition.
  - Energy must be absorbed for the electron to move away from a position closer to the nucleus ($n = 2$) to a position further from the nucleus ($n = 5$). Therefore, the absorption spectrum would show the wavelength of light energy absorbed to cause this transition. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    Although the electron has more kinetic energy closer to the nucleus, the electron has more potential energy. Energy input (absorption) is required to move the electron away from the nucleus. The absorption spectrum would show a continuous spectrum with black lines (where the light is absorbed) at the wavelength corresponding to this particular transition.
  - Visible light $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    Transitions from higher energy levels to $n = 2$ represent the Balmer Series in the hydrogen atom and emit light in the visible spectrum. A transition in the opposite direction from $n = 2$ to a higher energy level will involve the same magnitude of energy, just absorbed rather than emitted.
  - Shorter wavelength $\checkmark$
    $n = 4$ to $n = 1$ is a higher energy transition due to the greater distance to $n = 1$ resulting from the convergence of the energy levels. Higher energy corresponds to a shorter wavelength. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    On the diagram in part (i), the distance from  $n = 4$ to $n = 1$ is greater than the distance from $n = 2$ to $n = 5$, and therefore more energy is involved in the $4 \longrightarrow 1$ transition.
    Using the equations $E = hf$ and $c = \lambda f$, one can see that energy and frequency are directly related, but frequency and wavelength are inversely related. Therefore, energy and wavelength are inversely related. The energy increases, so the wavelength decreases.

- 
  - $(1228\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1})(\dfrac{1000\,\text{J}}{1\,\text{kJ}})(\dfrac{1\,\text{mol}}{6.02\times 10^{23}}) = \answer{2.040\times 10^{-18}\,\text{J}}\,\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The energy value provided states the energy for a mole of electrons  (kJ mol$^{-1}$) undergoing this energy transition. The calculation involves converting $kJ$ to $J$ and dividing  by Avagadro's constant to determine the energy value for a single electron.
  - $\lambda = \dfrac{hc}{E} = \dfrac{(6.63\times 10^{-34}\,\text{J s})(3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1})}{(2.040\times 10^{-18}\,\text{J})} = \answer{9.750\times 10^{-8}\,\text{m}}\,\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The calculation involves the equations, $E = hf$ and $c = \lambda f$
  - Ultraviolet $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    Using the electromagnetic spectrum (table 3 in the data booklet), a wavelength with the magnitude $10^{-8}$ to $10^{-9}$ would fall in the UV portion of the spectrum.
  - Transitions between energy levels within the atom involve specific amounts of energy. The transition from $4 \longrightarrow 1$ in the hydrogen atom will always emit the same amount of energy and produce the same spectral line. $\checkmark$
    The photons emitted by the transition $4 \longrightarrow 1$ are of a specific frequency and have discrete values because the electrons in the energy levels hold specific amounts of energy. $\checkmark$
    The response should describe the Bohr concept that the electrons reside in specific energy levels and therefore have specific amounts of energy. As they transition to lower energy levels as in 4 $\longrightarrow$ 1, photons are emitted with discrete amounts of energy having specific wavelengths and frequencies, they are said to be quantized.
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The Bohr model puts electrons in specific energy levels, Their energy in any particular level can be calculated. In the hydrogen atom, transitions from higher to lower energy levels emit photons of light of specific wavelength and frequency, they therefore carry an exact or discrete amount of energy and are quantized.

list.title: Question 58
list.content:
Which of the following is the correct electron configuration for iron in $\ce{FeCl2}?$


- A. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6$
- B. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^4$
- C. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\  3d^6$
- D. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^8$
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The ground$\text{--}$state electron configuration of neutral iron is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6.$ In $\ce{FeCl2},$ iron has a $2+$ charge so two electrons are removed from the iron atom. In transition metals, electrons are removed from the $4s$ sublevel first, not $3d,$ even though $4s$ is filled before $3d.$
Therefore, $\ce{Fe^2+}$ has the configuration $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 3d^6.$

list.title: Question 59
list.content:
Which gives the correct electron configuration for the chromium atom, Cr, and the chromium cation, $\ce{Cr+}$?


- CrCr$\mathbf{^+}$A.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^2$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^1$B.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^5 4s^1$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^1$C.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^2$[Ar] $3d^3 4s^2$D.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^5 4s^1$[Ar] $3d^5$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Chromium is an exception to the rule for the first$-$row $d-$block elements due to the stability of a half$-$filled $d-$subshell. When forming a positive ion, electrons are first lost from $4s$ and then $3d$.

list.title: Question 60
list.content:
The graph below shows the successive ionization energy data for an unknown metal M.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/52199042-cddb-421f-b65d-11e90428d392/images/555bf712-15ca-47f4-8685-1f60dc9bef9a/CH1251.png)


What is the likely formula of the oxide formed with this metal?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{MO}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{MO_2}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{M_2O}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{M_2O_3}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The graph shows a large jump after the removal of the first electron, which indicates that this metal has just one valence electron. This places it in group 1 of the periodic table. In group 1 metals, the second electron lies in an inner energy level, much closer to the nucleus and much more difficult to remove, which explains the sudden increase in ionization energy.
A group 1 metal forms a monovalent cation, $\ce{M^+}$, which bonds ionically with oxide, $\ce{O^{2-}}$. To achieve charge balance, two $\ce{M^+}$ ions combine with one $\ce{O^{2-}}$, giving the formula $\ce{M2O}$.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must deduce the group of the metal to figure out the formula of the compound formed with oxygen.

list.title: Question 61
list.content: - On the axis below, sketch the trend in first ionization energies for the elements in the second period. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9b45cc58-e523-4f52-864e-eae23e608867/images/f1506e00-a0e4-493b-9ce0-8aeaf0b1d48e/CH0601.png) - - Explain the general trend in first ionization energies. [2] - Predict whether the first ionization energies for the third period elements will be higher, lower or the same as their respective elements in the second period. [1]
list.markScheme:
- $\mbox{}$
  
  
  - ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9b45cc58-e523-4f52-864e-eae23e608867/images/2eab7790-1276-4d2c-be9c-c2ceae5ab875/CH0601-1.png)


   

  $\textit{General increasing trend}\, \checkmark$
$\textit{Drop between Be and B}\,\checkmark$
$\textit{Drop between N and O}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  More electron-electron repulsion in O (easier to remove the first electron).
  It is easier to remove the electron from the 2p$_x$ orbital in B since 2p is higher in energy than 2s in Be.
- 
  - The first ionization energy increases. $\checkmark$
    Same shielding AND increasing nuclear charge. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    The valence electrons are in the same energy level where there is no change in/additional shielding. Since the nuclear charge increases, there is a higher force of attraction, and more energy is required.
  - Lower. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    As electrons are further from the nucleus, with additional shells and therefore shielding, there is a reduced electrostatic force of attraction between the nucleus and the outermost electrons.

list.title: Question 62
list.content:
The graph below shows the successive ionization energies for an atom of an element.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bc94e49-7fd3-4b70-a969-ef5f078da97d/images/83b03c82-82b4-4c1b-b650-67ea3e3bcb90/CH0687.png)


Which element could be represented by this graph?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$O
- B. $\hspace{1em}$S
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Be
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Mg
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Large increase between the second and third ionization energies provides evidence that the element is in group 2 (Be or Mg).
Be only has four electrons, so this data could not be for an atom of beryllium.

list.title: Question 63
list.content: [Maximum marks: 10] Magnesium is an element in group 2 of the periodic table. - State the full electron configuration for magnesium and the block it can be found in the periodic table. [2] - Explain how successive ionization energies can prove that magnesium is in group 2 and period 3 of the periodic table. [3] - State the equation for the second ionization energy of magnesium. [1] - State an equation for the reaction between magnesium oxide and water, and comment on the pH of the resultant solution. [2] - By referring to their relative ionization energies, compare the metallic behavior of magnesium to calcium and beryllium (values from the data booklet are not required). [2]
list.markScheme:
- $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2$; $\checkmark$
  $s$ (block). $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  The $3s$ subshell is the highest energy subshell placing magnesium in the $s$-block.
- Group 2: Large increase in energy between 2$^{nd}$ and 3$^{rd}$ ionization energies shows that there are two electrons in the outermost shell. $\checkmark$
  Period 3: Two significant increases in energy (between 2$^{nd}$ and 3$^{rd}$, and 10$^{th}$ and 11$^{th}$ ionization energies) shows that there are three distinct energy levels. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Large increases in ionization energy suggest an electron is being removed from an energy level closer to the nucleus.
- $\ce{Mg+(g) -> Mg^2+(g) + e-}\,\checkmark$
  State symbols required
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  The second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous singly positive ions. This equation follows from the first ionization energy definition, which must be known.
- $\ce{MgO(s) + H2O(l) -> Mg(OH)2(aq)}\,\checkmark$
  State symbols NOT required
  pH greater than 7 $\checkmark$
  ALLOW any value greater than 7
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Metallic hydroxides are basic.
- Calcium is more metallic than magnesium, AND beryllium is less metallic than magnesium $\checkmark$
  Ionization energies decrease down group 2 $\checkmark$
  Metals have a greater tendency to lose electrons OR are more easily oxidized OWTTE $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 64
list.content:
Which of the following best explains why dark lines appear in the following spectrum?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5365ef0-5209-4ec6-ac9b-a2122f77697a/images/9e7287da-5026-4ca4-8933-7137e113e049/CH2145.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Dark lines in an absorption spectrum are caused by electrons in atoms absorbing photons of specific energies. These energies correspond to the difference between allowed energy levels in the atom. When atoms absorb those photons, the electrons are excited to higher energy levels, and the absorbed wavelengths are missing from the observed spectrum, creating dark lines.
Some answers might seem tempting but are incorrect. For example, photons are not emitted when electrons are excited because energy must be absorbed for an electron to move to a higher level. Likewise, when electrons fall to lower energy levels, they emit photons, which is how emission spectra are formed. Suggesting that photons are absorbed while electrons fall is inaccurate, since falling to a lower energy level releases energy rather than requiring it.

list.title: Question 65
list.content:
The first ionization energy of rubidium is $403\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.$ What is the wavelength of convergence for the rubidium atomic spectrum?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2970\,\text{nm}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}297\,\text{nm}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}2.97 \times 10^{-4}\,\text{m}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}4.93 \times 10^{-31}\,\text{m}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The convergence limit in an atomic spectrum corresponds to the energy required to remove an electron from the ground state of the atom, which is the first ionization energy. To use this value, it must first be expressed per atom rather than per mole:
$E_\ce{photon} = \dfrac{\textrm{IE}}{N_A} = \dfrac{403\times 10^3\text{\ J mol}^{-1}}{6.02\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}} = 6.69\times 10^{-19}\text{\ J}$
This is the energy of a single photon at the convergence limit. Using the relationship $E = \dfrac{hc}{λ},$ the wavelength can be determined.
$\lambda = \dfrac{hc}{E} = \dfrac{(6.63\times 10^{-34}\,\text{J s})(3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1})}{6.69\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}} = 2.97\times 10^{-7}\,\text{m} = \answer{297\,\text{nm}}$
The question is of medium difficulty because it requires students to connect the concept of ionization energy with the convergence limit, perform a unit conversion from per mole to per photon, and express the final result using the correct SI prefix.

list.title: Question 66
list.content:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful diagnostic tool commonly used in medicine. They operate at a frequency of approximately $2.00 \times 10^2$ MHz. Using Section 5 of the IB Chemistry data booklet, in what region of the spectrum do MRI machines operate?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Radio
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Microwaves
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Infrared
- D.$\hspace{1em}$X$-$ray
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
A frequency of $2.00 \times 10^2$ MHz equals $2.00 \times 10^8$ Hz (1 MHz = $1 \times 10^6$ Hz).
Frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional according to the equation, c = $\lambda f$.
$\lambda$ = $\dfrac{c}{f}$ = $\dfrac{3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1}}{2.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ s}^{-1}} = 1.5 \textrm{\ m}$
This wavelength lies in the radiowave portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.

list.title: Question 67
list.content:
The successive ionization energies for an unknown element are shown in the graph below. Which of the following statements regarding this element are correct?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2db804f3-104c-455a-aca4-896f6a765086/images/2e72a968-a136-4f83-8d80-c2744eefff9a/CH0778.png)




- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Removal of the 4th electron is from a different energy level than the first 3 electrons.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$This element belongs in Group 13 on the periodic table.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$The effective nuclear charge is decreasing with the removal of successive electrons.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I, II, and III
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
There is a disproportionate increase in ionization energy between the removal of the 3rd and 4th electron. Therefore, this element has 3 valence electrons, and the removal of the 4th electron would come from a lower energy level, and the element belongs in Group 13.
With the removal of each subsequent electron, the remaining electrons experience less interference with one another and will experience a greater pull from the nucleus.

list.title: Question 68
list.content:
Which statement(s) is(are) correct for chromium?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$The electron configuration for its divalent cation is $\ce{[Ar]}3d^5.$
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$It belongs to the $d-$block.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$Its condensed electronic configuration is $\ce{[Ar]}4s^2\,3d^4.$



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$III only
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Neutral chromium has the observed ground$-$state configuration $\ce{[Ar]}4s^1 \,3d^5$ (the $4s$ and $3d$ subshells are very close in energy, and the $4s^1 \,3d^5$
arrangement is lower in energy than $4s^2 \, 3d^4$ for the atom). Statement III is false.
When chromium cations form, the $4s$ electrons are removed before the $3d$ electrons (electrons are removed from the highest $n$ level). For $\ce{Cr^{2+}},$ the electron configuration is $\ce{[Ar]}3d^4.$ Statement I is false.
With its highest$-$energy electrons in the $3d$ subshell, chromium belongs to the $d-$block transition metals.  Its placement in the periodic table supports this assessment.  Statement II is true.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3984ad5b-c9b4-4c1f-b0cd-bb001f4e6c5c/images/661f93f8-2ee6-44fe-9c0f-89c979cd5c80/CH1222.png)

list.title: Question 69
list.content:
Which statements about successive ionization energies of sodium are correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$They show an increasing trend as the number of electrons removed increases.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$There is a significant jump from the second to the third ionization energy.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$There is a significant jump from the ninth to the tenth ionization energy.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Successive ionization energies ($\ce{IE}_n$) always increase as electrons are removed from an increasingly positive ion and from orbitals of lower energy, so statement I is correct.
Sodium has the ground$-$state configuration $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1.$ The largest jump for Na occurs when you cross from removing the valence electron to removing a core electron. For Na, $\ce{IE}_1$ removes the $3s$ electron; $\ce{IE}_2$ begins removing $n=2$ core electrons. Thus the big discontinuity is between $\ce{IE}_1$ and $\ce{IE}_2,$ (not between $\ce{IE}_2$ and $\ce{IE}_3.$ Statement II is incorrect.
After nine electrons have been removed $(\ce{IE}_1$ through
$\ce{IE}_9),$ the remaining configuration is $1s^2.$ The tenth ionization must remove a $1s$ electron (crossing from the $n=2$ shell into the $n=1$ shell), which requires a dramatically larger energy. Therefore there is a second clear jump from $\ce{IE}_9$ to $\ce{IE}_{10},$ so statement III is correct.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must be able to deduce the pattern for successive ionization energies of a given atom.

list.title: Question 70
list.content:
Successive ionization energies for elements $X$ and $Y$ in $\textrm{kJ\, mol}^{-1}$ are shown in the table below. Which of the following ionic compounds is most likely to be formed when elements $X$ and $Y$ react?
$\newline$


- Successive Ionization Energies (kJ mol$^\mathbf{-1}$)
- $\enskip$Element$\enskip$1$^{\mathbf{st}}$2$^{\mathbf{nd}}$3$^{\mathbf{rd}}$4$^{\mathbf{th}}$5$^{\mathbf{th}}$6$^{\mathbf{th}}$7$^{\mathbf{th}}$8$^{\mathbf{th}}$$X$738$\enskip1450\enskip$$\enskip7730 \enskip$$\enskip10500\enskip$$\enskip13600\enskip $$\enskip18000\enskip$$\enskip21700\enskip$$\enskip25700\enskip$$Y$$\enskip$1250$\enskip$230038205160654093601100033600



- A. $\hspace{1em}$XY
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ X$_2$Y
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ XY$_2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$XY$_3$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$X$ is in Group 2, as there is a large increase between the 2nd and 3rd ionization energies.
$Y$ is in Group 17, as there is a large increase between the 7th and 8th ionization energies.
Group 2 elements form 2+ ions, Group 17 forms $1-$ ions.

list.title: Question 71
list.content:
The figure shows the visible line emission spectrum of hydrogen.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/3c917e33-7871-4db3-92fb-7ba883f0f5f8/CH2146.png)


Which of the following transitions is most likely responsible for the red line in the spectrum?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n = 5\longrightarrow n = 2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n = 2\longrightarrow n = 1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n = 4\longrightarrow n = 2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n = 3\longrightarrow n = 2$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\text{Explanation:}}$
The red line marked in the figure is the longest-wavelength of the four visible lines and must come from the smallest energy drop that ends at the second energy level. Of the options given, the transition from $n = 3$ down to $n = 2$ fits that description: it releases less energy than drops from $n = 4$ or $n = 5$ to $n = 2,$ so its photon has a longer wavelength and appears red. The $n = 2 \longrightarrow n = 1$ transition is ruled out because it ends at the first level and produces ultraviolet light, which is not visible in the spectrum shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/058442e4-9a9f-423c-b942-81f41aad4b2c/CH2146ans.JPEG)

list.title: Question 72
list.content:
The table below shows the successive ionization energies of two elements X and Y.
Number of electrons $\newline$ removedIonization energy of X $\newline$ / kJ mol$\mathbf{^{-1}}$Ionization energy of Y $\newline$ / kJ mol$\mathbf{^{-1}}$149610002456222523691033574954345565133547004616613849672011727107
Which is the correct formula for the compound formed between X and Y?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The student must deduce the corresponding group of elements X and Y from the successive ionization energies given. An element's successive ionization energies increase as more energy is needed to remove electrons.  As the ion becomes more positive, it will take more energy to remove the next electron.  Successive ionization energies always increase. When the next electron is in a shell closer to the nucleus, the successive ionization energy will increase sharply because there is less shielding of the nuclear charge and because the distance between the electron and nucleus is smaller.
In the table provided, the largest jump in the ionization energy for element X occurs between $IE_1$ (first ionization energy) and $IE_2$ (second ionization energy). This must correspond to a change in energy level. So, the atom of the element must have one valence electron and belong to group 1. In the case of Y, the largest jump in the ionization energy occurs between $IE_6$ (sixth ionization energy) and $IE_7$ (seventh ionization energy). So, the atom of the element must have six valence electrons and belong to group 16.
X forms cations with one positive charge whereas Y forms ions with two negative charges. As a result, the combination of $\ce{X+}$ and $\ce{Y^{2-}}$ is $\ce{X2Y}.$
This question is categorized as a medium as the student must use the information from successive ionization energies to deduce the corresponding group for the elements and then figure out how these are combined together.

list.title: Question 73
list.content: Ionization energy data for the elements can be used to provide evidence for energy levels and sublevels within the atom. - The diagram below shows the amount of energy required to remove the first 10 electrons from a period 3 element. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/936356f8-e31b-4bf2-99a4-07f670f2d94b/images/e1a82b9f-5b5a-4cb0-a4b3-1a3d8405c221/CH0786a.png) - Write an equation that represents the third ionization energy of an element. You can use A as the symbol for the unknown element. [2] - Identify the period 3 element and explain how the ionization data shown above supports your response. [3] - Explain why the ionization data increases as subsequent electrons are removed from the atom. [1] - Write the electron configuration for the commonly formed ion of this period 3 element. [1] - The diagram below shows the first ionization energies of the elements across period 3. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/936356f8-e31b-4bf2-99a4-07f670f2d94b/images/6eee7b19-a1b4-45d8-880e-a5473303b658/CH0786b.png) - Explain how the first ionization data shown can be used to support the existence of the $s$ and $p$ sublevels of period 3. [4] - Explain why argon has such a high first ionization energy. [1]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\ce{A^2+(g) -> A^3+(g) + e-}\,\checkmark\checkmark$
Award M2 for state symbols.
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Ionization energy is the energy required to remove an electron from a ground$-$state gas$-$phase atom or ion. The removal of the third successive electron would come from the ion of the element that has already lost 2 electrons ($\ce{A^{2+}}$). Removal of the third electron would change the ion to $\ce{A^{3+}}$.
  - Magnesium  / Mg $\checkmark$
large jump between 2$^{nd}$ and 3$^{rd}$ ionization energy, 3$^{rd}$electron from inner energy level $\checkmark$
two valence electrons $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Looking at the graph, there is a larger step (nonlinear) increase in the subsequent ionization energies for the removal of the third electron. This means the first two electrons are removed from the valence energy level, while the third is removed from an inner energy level, in this case the second energy level since the element is in period 3.
  - more positively changed ion, stronger attraction to the nucleus $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Since ionization energy is the energy required to completely move the electron from the atom or ion, as the charge on the nucleus increases, the ionization energy must therefore increase.
  - $\ce{1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The period 3 element is magnesium with two valence electrons in the $3s$ sublevel. Losing these two electrons leaves a the period 2 energy level, with $s$ and $p$ sublevels complete.

- 
  - drop in ionization energy from Mg to Al $\checkmark$
electrons in $3p$ subshell partially shielded by $3s$ electrons  $\checkmark$
drop in the ionization energy moving from P to S $\checkmark$
fourth electron in $3p$ subshell experiences increased $\ce{e-}-\ce{e-}$ repulsion $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The trend of ionization energy across period 3 is generally upward due to the increasing nuclear charge pulling the outer electrons closer. However, the data also show irregularities that can only be explained by sublevels. The first occurs between magnesium and aluminium: in aluminium, the electron removed is from a $3p$ orbital, which lies at slightly higher energy and is shielded by the inner 3s orbital. This makes it easier to remove than the $3s$ electron in magnesium. A second dip occurs between phosphorus and sulfur. Phosphorus has three unpaired $3p$ electrons, but sulfur has a fourth $3p$ electron that must pair with one of the others. The repulsion between two electrons in the same orbital lowers the energy required to remove one, creating the observed decrease. These two dips are direct experimental evidence that period 3 contains both $3s$ and $3p$ sublevels.
  - Ar has highest effective nuclear charge , same shielding $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Argon lies at the end of period 3, where the nuclear charge is greatest. Its outer electrons are still in the $n=3$ shell, but they experience a strong effective nuclear charge because shielding from inner electrons is relatively constant across the period. This strong attraction between nucleus and outer $3p$ electrons requires much more energy to remove them, so argon shows the highest first ionization energy of period 3.

list.title: Question 74
list.content:
Which of the following statements about electron spin is correct?


- I.Unpaired electrons occupy separate orbitals within a sublevel before pairing occurs.II.Two electrons in the same orbital must have parallel spins.III.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows two electrons to occupy the same orbital.



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
According to Hund's Rule, electrons fill orbitals of the same sublevel singly and with parallel spins before any pairing occurs. This minimizes electron-electron repulsion and leads to a more stable, lower-energy configuration. Statement I is correct.
Electrons in the same orbital must have opposite spins, not parallel spins, to satisfy the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which prevents two electrons in the same orbital from having identical properties. Statement II is incorrect.
Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows them to share an orbital, as long as their spins are opposite ($\uparrow$ and $\downarrow$). This difference in spin enables two electrons to occupy the same spatial region without violating exclusion rules. Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 75
list.content:
Which energy transition in the hydrogen emission spectrum has the highest frequency?


- A.$\hspace{1em}n = 3$ to $n = 1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}n = 3$ to $n = 2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}n = 4$ to $n = 3$
- D.$\hspace{1em}n = 4$ to $n = 1$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Below is the energy level diagram of hydrogen.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59852886-12f9-4f0c-bdd6-5e47eba81474/images/4de51eb8-2a0c-4b0e-a1ee-a2a3a35a8b38/CH1154.png)

Based on the equation $E=hf$, the greater the energy of the emission, the greater the frequency of the emission. The four transitions are shown below.

Transition D is the one with the greatest energy emission and the one with the greatest frequency.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must recall the energy level diagram of hydrogen and compare different emissions.

list.title: Question 76
list.content:
Which of the following correctly describes the electron configuration of the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion?


- Number of occupied $p$ sublevelsNumber of occupied $p$ orbitalsA.$\hspace{1em}$26B.212C.62D.122
list.markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion, the electron configuration is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6.$ This means that two $p$ sublevels are occupied: $2p$ and $3p.$ Each of these sublevels includes three $p$ orbitals, and in this case, all six $p$ orbitals are fully occupied. Understanding the distinction between sublevels and orbitals is essential to interpreting electron configurations accurately.

list.title: Question 77
list.content: The successive ionization energies for element X are shown in the table below: $\textbf{Successive Ionization Energies (kJ mol}^{\mathbf{-1}})$1st IE2nd IE3rd IE4th IE5th IE6th IE7th IE8th IE1000225233634556700484962710831724 - Write the equation that represents the second ionization energy of element X. [1] - Predict the number of valence electrons for element X and justify your response. [2] - Another element, Y, is found below and in the same group as element X in the periodic table. The electronegativity value of element Y is 2.6. Predict a reasonable value for the electronegativity value of element X. Explain your reasoning.[2]
list.markScheme:
- $\ce{X^+(g) -> X^{2+}(g) + e^-}$ $\checkmark$
State symbols must be shown.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of singly positive gaseous ions.
- element X has 6 valence electrons $\checkmark$
large jump between 6th and 7th IE $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
There is a large increase moving from the 6th IE to the 7th IE. This indicates that the 7th electron must be removed from a lower energy level closer to the nucleus as substantially more energy is required to remove the 7th electron.
- value between 2.6 and 3.4 $\checkmark$ 
smaller atom has higher electronegativity $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Element Y lies in the same group and below element X. Therefore, element Y has more energy levels in its atom than element X. Electronegativity is the attraction the atom of an element has for the shared pair of electrons in a covalent bond. This attraction will increase when there are fewer energy levels; hence electrons are closer to the nucleus or the atom, and the element has a higher electronegativity value.  The most electronegative atom in Group 16 is oxygen with 3.4.

list.title: Question 78
list.content:
Two elements, X and Y, have the following successive ionization energies (in $\text{kJ mol}^{-1}):$
Element1st2nd3rd4th5th6thX73814517733105431363018020Y1012190729144964624721267
What is the most likely formula of the compound formed when X and Y combine?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{X3Y2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
First, the student must use the information about successive ionization energies to deduce the group of both elements. For element X, there is a significant jump in ionization energy between the second and third ionization energies (from $1451\text{kJ mol}^{-1}$ to $7733\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}),$ indicating that the first two electrons are valence electrons. Therefore, X has two valence electrons and belongs to Group 2. For element Y, a large jump occurs between the fifth and sixth ionization energies (from $6247\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$ to $21267\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}),$ suggesting that the first five electrons are valence electrons. Thus, Y has five valence electrons and belongs to Group 15.
Second, the student must determine the preferred charge of each of the elements to find the most likely compound that they would form. Element X, with two valence electrons, will likely lose both to form the $\ce{X^2+}$ ion, while element Y, with five valence electrons, will likely gain three electrons to form the $\ce{Y^3-}$ ion. To balance the charges in a neutral compound, three $\ce{X^2+}$ ions will combine with two $\ce{Y^3-}$ ions, resulting in the formula $\ce{X3Y2}.$
This question is categorized as medium difficulty because it requires analyzing ionization energy trends, deducing ionic charges, and balancing charges to determine the correct formula of the compound.

list.title: Question 79
list.content:
The wavelength for a particular electron transition in an element is measured to be 600 nm.
Which calculation below represents the correct calculation for the determination of the energy of a mole of electrons undergoing this transition (in $\textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1})?$


- A.$\hspace{1em}\dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34})(3.00 \times 10^8)(6.02 \times 10^{23})}{ (600)(1000)}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\dfrac{(6.00 \times 10^{-7})(1000)}{ (6.63 \times 10^{-34})(3.00 \times 10^8)(6.02 \times 10^{23})}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34})(3.00 \times 10^8)(1000)}{(6.00 \times 10^{-7})(6.02 \times 10^{23})}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34})(3.00 \times 10^8)(6.02 \times 10^{23})}{ (6.00 \times 10^{-7})(1000)}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Using the equations $c = \lambda f$ and $E = hf$ from the data booklet, the energy of one mole of photons with a wavelength of 600 nm can be determined. The energy of one photon is
$E_{\ce{photon}} = hf = \dfrac{hc}{\lambda}$
and the energy of 1 mole of phtons is
$E = \dfrac{hcN_A}{\lambda}$
Plugging in the values:
$E = \dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34} \textrm{\ J s})(3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1})(6.02 \times 10^{23} \textrm{\ mol}^{-1})}{600 \textrm{\ nm}}$
To get the final answer in $\textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1}$, J must be converted to kJ and nm to m.
$E = \dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34} \textrm{\ J s})\left(\dfrac{1 \textrm{\ kJ}}{1000 \textrm{\ J}}\right)(3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1})(6.02 \times 10^{23} \textrm{\ mol}^{-1})}{600 \textrm{\ nm}\times\dfrac{1 \textrm{\ m}}{10^9 \textrm{\ nm}}}$$E = \dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34})(3.00 \times 10^8 )(6.02 \times 10^{23})}{(6.00 \times 10^{-7})(1000) }$
$\ $

list.title: Question 80
list.content:
Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom emission spectrum emits radiation with the highest frequency?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n=1\longrightarrow n=7$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n=7 \longrightarrow n=1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n=5 \longrightarrow n=2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n=4 \longrightarrow n=3$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To answer this question, students must differentiate emission (electrons decaying to a lower energy level) from absorption (electrons promoted to higher energy levels).
Students should also recall the relationship between frequency and energy ($E \propto f$). The highest frequency corresponds to the highesy energy transition.  According to the Bohr model, thediscrete energy levels in the hydrogen spectrum converge at higher energies. Of the three emissions proposed, the one with the greatest frequency/energy is $n=7 \longrightarrow n=1.$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89299878-7c02-447d-9568-fe86fcf00643/images/1fae25df-afde-432d-9d9e-b4c45710afca/CH0994.JPEG)


This question is categorized as hard as students compare transitions based on their knowledge of the hydrogen energy level diagram.

list.title: Question 81
list.content:
Which electron transition in a hydrogen atom emits the longest wavelength of light?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n = 3$ to $n = 2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n = 4$ to $n = 3$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n = 5$ to $n = 4$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n = 2$ to $n = 1$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The electronic energy levels for the hydrogen atom converge at high energy (furthest from the nucleus), where $n = 1$ is closest to the nucleus. A simple diagram can be drawn to show the relative energy levels.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e38802a0-9d42-4913-b9b7-de2c97c3a807/images/a330f257-07c0-49ca-84ff-4a03ecd5af38/CH2032.png)


Each transition is indicated with an arrow, where the longest arrow equates to the highest energy. Energy and the wavelength of light are inversely proportional as follows:
$E = \dfrac{hc}{\lambda}$
Therefore, a higher energy has a lower wavelength (and vice versa). For this question, we are looking for the shortest arrow which is the lowest energy and the longest wavelength (so, $n= 5$ to $n = 4).$
